Discoverआणखी more - La Scogliera: https://www.kqzyfj.com/click-100692842-11552042?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tripadvisor.com%2FHotel_Review-g187821-d1557420-Reviews-La_Scogliera-Riomaggiore_Cinque_Terre_Italian_Riviera_Liguria.html%23%2Fmedia%2F1557420%2F50266399%3Ap%2F%3Falbumid%3D101%26type%3D2%26category%3D101

Planning a 2 week trip in late May 2024
Current itinerary is :
Venice 3 days
Tuscany 6 days (trips to Umbria and Florence) 5 days in Naples and surrounding area.
Plan to train Venice to Tuscany. Use a rental car in Tuscany. Train from Tuscany to Naples. Use public and private transport in Naples area.
Thoughts, suggestions? Thanks!

comments.comment_text: We are taking the train to Chiusi and renting a car at the train station in Chiusi. We are basing ourselves in nearby Pienza to explore the beautiful Val d’Orcia. We have no experience with renting a car in Chiusi but I read several comments that it’s a pretty easy process.

Italy has a no fault accident and they drive very aggressive!

You honestly don’t need to rent a vehicle in, public transportation is very good there or anywhere in Europe.

IMO 3 days in Venice is too long, I would say no more than 2. But that’s just me. . It’s like Pisa. You only need 1/2 or 1 day in Pisa if you went there. It’s so small and the real main attraction is the tower and church. It’s an easy train ride to/from Florence.

Naples is big and easy to get around with public transportation.
But I get the need to rent cars. I used to all the time. But I don’t anymore.

Just my 2¢
Stay in sorento instead of naples. For sure
I would also stay in Sorrento versus Naples. Naples is a bit rough and can be dangerous.

Hello i would suggest to add 1 day in Milan, so you can use public transport by high speed train front Venice to Milan then Milan to Florence and Florence to Naples. Please consider that May can be very hot!! I also suggest you to visit Pompei during your stay in Naples. I live close to Milan

Driving in the Tuscany region is not hard. It's mostly rural and lesser highways. But make sure you get an International Driver's Permit. AAA does them. And you need a car to really explore Tuscany. Even if the rental agency doesn't ask for an International Driver's Permit it is Italian law that you have to have one. If you get in an accident or get stopped the first thing they'll want in your IDP.
My thoughts, I want to go too……
I think it’s important to consider the first few days you’ll likely be affected by jet lag so it’s probably a good idea to have an extra day at your first stop.
Napoli 5 giorni è tantissimo,a meno che non vai in costiera amalfitana o a capri/Ischia.

text: My husband and I will be traveling from Venice to Rome via train. Is there a train station that is best to travel from? ￼￼￼ we are staying in the sun Marco area… thank you in advance for any help and insights!

comments.comment_text: There's only one train station in Venice, which is Santa Lucia. The other one (Venezia Mestre) is on the mainland, it's typically the first stop after Santa Lucia for outbound trains

I also stayed in San Marco as well. I walked from the hotel to Santa Lucia train station(took me 30mins) and took the Italo train to Rome Termini. I would have booked my ticket in advance as well. Then depending on where you're staying in Rome, you may need to take the tube to get where you're going in Rome.

Walking through Venezia allowed me to sightsee and see a less "touristy" areas of Venezia! Wish I ventured out of San Marco more! Enjoy!

text: Hi - is it possible to 'break a journey' on the train in Italy? For example: I am going to a concert and there is a special €10 ticket to purchase which includes a return train and shuttle to the venue. On the way I want to drop my back odd at my accommodation (near to one of the stops) and jump back on. Normally I wouldn't have any reservations, as I think Italian trains are fantastic, but last year I had a bad experience with the trains in the South of Italy and that's ruined things slightly! Thanks for your help :)

comments.comment_text: The trains tend to spend about 5-10 mins in each station. You might not make it back to the train in that time.
If you are getting off and leaving the station, you will need another ticket to get back on.
Ask at the train station. The ticket may have a time limit when you validate it
No lmao
Could you let me know if it’s a regional train or frecciarossa?
It depends. If it's a "regionale", it has a time limit of 4 hours after you've validated it, so you can get off and get on another one (unless the concert rules say otherwise).
Depends on where you’re coming from and your destination. If it’s in the same city, just get a day ticket.

text:
Hello

Firstly, please excuse this post. I’m a boomer and take terrible selfies, so please be kind. I’m going to Sicily and Rome next month. I have previously been to Italy and yes, I used the dreaded selfie stick and yes, I loved it.

My question is, do people still use them or are they an absolute NO NO? I have heard they are illegal?

thank you

comments.comment_text: Don’t feel shy to ask a family to take pic- offer to take theirs too! Plus if it’s a family for you know they’re not gonna run away with your phone. ￼ I also ordered a cute little tripod on Amazon and you can always set your phone down and take a step back and take a pic with a timer. But I think that having just gotten back from Spain there are lots and lots of places you can use a selfie stick.
who the heck said they are illegal.... thats not true.. no law against using them
I don’t have one, but thought about getting one. They seem fun and practical.
Can't avoid people trying to sell them to you. Continuously.
If you want to use one then use one, unless otherwise posted. It’s your life, live it to the fullest! Have a great trip!
Just returning from Florence and Liguria area. I didn't see anyone using them. My cousin lives there says they are forbidden in Portofino. Not sure about other towns.
They sell them everywhere.
They are practical for many and I say use it. The beauty of Italy is to take as many pics as you can to remember how wonderful a place it is. Enjoy your trip. 🇮🇹🤗
Non sono illegali
Seriously? I never would have thought/known that if I hadn’t read this post. As a solo traveller, I love a good selfie stick! Thanks for posting!
Just curious, why are they banned? Thanks
Just came back from Sicily last month and saw plenty of ppl using them
New Samsung has a feature where you can say word and the phone will take the photo
I used mine, badly! My cousin used the Bluetooth “clicker” so held phone in 1 had & clicked to take photo with other hand
They sold them everywhere around the touristy spots in Rome and Florence
Just ordered mine from Amazon and plan on using a lot, although not in museums

I’m bringing ours. The only place I read where you aren’t supposed to use them is the colosseum. I think the reason was because it’s too crowded and they didn’t want them used due to possible damage to the colosseum.
They were all over Rome 2 weeks ago. Not sure about anywhere else.
If u love using it, use it. Who cares what anyone thinks AT ALL
They’re still used and they’re only illegal in certain areas of cities

Saw loads of vendors selling them & hundreds of tourists using them all over Italy, from Lake Garda, Cinqueterre, Siena, Florence, Rome, Venice, Sorrento, Positano & Capri. We nearly bought one but the zoom out function worked fine or asked another tourist to take a photo for us. This was also a great way to meet people & swap travel tips!
Banned in some parts of Italy
I've seen them all over this week.
Get your guide
I’m taking mine to Lake Garda????
My husband bought one for our trip in September and we are millennials we want to be in as many pictures together as we can . ￼
Certain indoor places ban them but widely used outside. I just asked several people to take a photo & returned favor instead of using mine.
We just bought one for $5 because we were sick of looking like 2 bobble heads in our pics. Best $5 spent!!
We’ve just come back from Naples, Rome, Sorrento and Amalfi and they are everywhere. Have fun with that stick.
I read they are outlawed in Portofino but haven’t heard they are illegal in other places.
Just got back from five weeks in Italy. Many places say no to them, many say yes. It’s about 50-50. Bring it if you want and know when to use it. Have fun.

Well I don’t know if they are illegal but they do discourage folks standing in front of statues, duomos fountains etc for “lengths” of time trying to get just the right shot. In other works, take a selfie and move along to avoid creating congestion. Have fun, great country and plenty of photo opportunities.
I just left Italy yesterday and saw tons of people with selfie sticks, especially vendors
Not illegal but definitely a problem in crowded areas. Really, just use your arm and get the broader background in a separate shot
Im going in aug dont give a shit im using my selfie
Italy is only place I’ve seen selfie sticks recently

Lmao. I’m 69 and I just got back from a trip to France with 3 other HS friends. One brought with her an old selfie stick but lacked the proper attachment to her current iPhone. One young man came to the rescue with the appropriate dongle and we had so much ridiculous fun trying to use it from inadvertent videos and bad shots. It became a joke to use it wherever we went. We even turned away people offering to take a photo for us. Lmao. We will have laughs for years looking at these shots and videos.
But to answer your question, not many folks using selfie sticks and some tourist attractions have banned them. 🙃
They had signs in Rome near the colosseum and palatine that said they were not allowed, I still saw people using them
Selfie sticks are indeed banned in some Italian cities and you can be fined for using one in public spaces. Additionally, most museums and churches also have bans in place.
I also used mine on the Bernini Express and got some great videos through the windows. Plus, popped out of the sunroof on our vintage Fiat 500 tour. Use them sensibly and you'll be fine 🙂

When we travelled in May we had no problems and there were no signs or warnings. My husband handled the selfies with our stick and I took all the other sightseeing pictures. We never held up traffic or took too much time, I think that’s key.
I'm Italian. Usually they are used only by tourists but don't worry, they're allowed 😊

If you don’t use selfie stick top tip is to use the zoom out function on phone - I have short arms and this defo helps - this was me trying a selfie 🤣 and the. My friend said “why are you nit using zoom out function”
Certainly saw them in Positano

They use them there and in Spain
I'm consistently getting hit in the head with them, walking around Barcelona

We never had one. I wish I did. Italy, Scotland, Ireland, England France, Germany. I have photos from a few years of trips and don’t like most photos of me. My husband said no his arm is long enough. And they are a pain to carry. Heading back to France next week and maybe I bring one with me this time. (He’s not along anyway) but my girlfriend will be mortified
We took one and used it many places. They weren’t not allowed in some places and were checked at the door and we picked it up on our way out. Backpacks the same in some places as well tho.

Rome weather forecast for Tuesday July 18: High of 43deg Celcuis or 109deg Fahrenheit.
Take care.
The phones have settings for a wide angle. I don't think it's really necessary.
We were in Florence and many people had them - there were people also selling them on the streets!
We’re bringing a selfie stick but obviously will not use where not allowed.
I haven’t seen any in a few years
People still use them, just bring one.
I dare you to use one while ordering cappuccino in the evening. Seriously we saw plenty about, not my scene and no idea on the legallites. Have a great trip.

The article below dates back to. 2015. As a visitor to ANY country, respect their rules and laws. I’m getting tired hear reading “nobody cares”. Yes, the locals do care, but are too polite to say anything.

New York City is really taking a stand against selfie sticks cluttering up popular tourist sites. So many museums ban sticks, including: the Met, the MOMA, Brooklyn Museum, Cooper Hewitt Museum, Guggenheim Museum, the Frick, the Whitney, and American Museum of Natural History are on it.
Rest of the U.S.
Outside of New York's museum scene, other tourist spots in the U.S. are also cracking down on the gadget.
Across the nation selfie sticks are banned at: Washington D.C.'s Smithsonian museums, the Art Institute of Chicago, the Getty Center in LA, the Cleveland Museum of Art(opens in a new tab), the Carnegie Museums(opens in a new tab) of Pittsburgh, the Blanton Museum of Art(opens in a new tab) in Austin, Texas, the Perot Museum of Nature and Science(opens in a new tab) in Dallas, Texas, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston(opens in a new tab), Detroit Institute of the Arts, and the Seattle Art Museum(opens in a new tab).
Don t remember seeing them...

My husband swore he’d never ever buy one, he admitted defeat when he purchased one in Rome. We’ve gotten some great shots that we wouldn’t have been able to get if we hadn’t got one. I’d advise to take it with you and see how you go. Good luck! 😊🇨🇮
I'm older and my selfies suck so bad that I refuse to do them. lol. Love this post.
Selfie sticks arab must, I forget about mine a lot. I used it in the colosseum. Some museums say they're not allowed, couldn't use it in the vatican. Just bring it.
I seen tourists use them here
I’ve seen a few this week. You do you.
We were in Rome in April. I can't remember seeing anyone with a selfie stick
I saw lots of them over the past 3 weeks that we travelled around. No big deal
why selfies, just photograph the beautiful place and enjoy
Street vendors are still selling them. But please do not use them in tight quarters.

Tons of people use them while I was in Italy last month ..
Do what works for u & enjoy !
Its ok,unless you will do it at the top of gianicolo hill or terrazze del pincio and you will fall down 😂😂😂❤
As we were 2 families, 8 of us, that selfie stick came out everywhere!! It helped in getting the perfect group shots every place we ventured to!
I don’t have the arm span to take a selfie so I’m bringing one.

We used one on our recent visit and wouldn't have got the photos we wanted without one. The vendors were still walking around main tourist sights selling them too. We never encountered any issues and travelled to Milan, Lake Garda, Verona, Florence, Lake Como and St Moritz on our trip. ENJOY 🇮🇹
Da italiana ti rispondo che solo i turisti lo usano

If you have an Apple Watch, you can use the Camera remote feature on there. Someone still has to hold out the phone, but they don't have to push the button. The watch feature gives you three seconds to pose.

text: Hi we are arriving at Brindisi airport next week at 23.30 am thinking of hiring a car prior to our arrivial bse we will be heading to otranto were our hotell is located.was wondering if there any car hire companies that are open at 23.30 in Brindisi??Thank you

comments.comment_text: Appears Thrifty are 24 hours from this on their website but always good to check

text: Booked 6 nights in Florence and aim to do day trips as travelling with family of 7 so wanted a base. Day trips to Rome, Venice, Cinque/Pisa - any suggestions re trains and other recommendations for day trips? Also what’s train trip from Paris to Florence and vice versa like. Flights easier? We were looking at flights from Florence to Amsterdam then finish up in Paris but it’s costly

comments.comment_text: Paris is a nightmare at the moment. So so busy, roadworks everywhere and everything is getting renovated for the Olympics. Tickets for museums ect impossible to get. Look at another place instead.
C t Is a seven hour round trip from florence without any traffic. Replan where you plan on taking your day trips

Sounds like a memorable trip.

I would suggest that you be aware of planned transportation (train, airport) strikes. They are generally announced in advance so you can make alternate plans.
Look up Florencetown for small group or private tours. They save you the hassle of worrying about train strikes, parking, figuring out all the logistics, etc. We loved their Cinque Terre tour!

I personally wouldn’t do any day trips from Florence towards Rome. Can you fly into Rome, stay there for a few days and move up to Florence? Six nights it’s not a lot for what there is to see. You could split three days Rome, three days Florence. But you really don’t have time for any of the other areas you would like to see. If you want to do a appetizer of each city, you could do two days Rome, two days Florence, two days Venice. I think that would be better than taking the trains back-and-forth,
which would mean you’re spending a third of your day on the train travelling, as opposed to actually enjoying the city you are in. Is Paris on top of the six days? If so, definitely fly. We flew from Venice to Paris one year and it was about an hour long flight. I would only do that if you actually had a few more days to spend in Paris though. Otherwise use the extra time in one of the Italian cities. ￼￼

text: I’m just starting to plan our first trip to Italy. Family of 5. Wow is it overwhelming lol, but exciting. We will be there 8-10 days I’m thinking . May 2024. We don’t want to cram too many places in, I’d rather take our time and really explore. I’m thinking 2 home bases. I’m torn between Rome and Tuscany or maybe Naples and Almafi ???? I’d like some history and tours , but we love nature/countryside and the ocean lol. So I’m at a total loss. Any advice ? Or a different itinerary idea? Thank you

comments.comment_text: Rome and Florence

Country side is definately tuscany outside of Florence as and Florence I fell on love with. My second favorite is Sorrento brings u to the amalfi coast and Capri. These are my two favorites. I love nature and shopping.

If you can extend it to 14 days that would be ideal to split two home bases. We did this last October. A week in a villa in the Florence hills and a week in Capri. I would recommend a week somewhere in Tuscany so you can explore that area and a week on or near the Amalfi Coast. Sorrento would be work well as there are lots of places you can explore from there. Two very different regions of Italy. They will not disappoint!
The amalfi coast is literally the most serene and beautiful place on earth. I’ve been many times and choose to go back over exploring new places
First trip means the main cities……Rome, to Florence and day trips from Florence, Milan and home.
Cinque Terre!! and Lucca
Rome & Tuscany or Rome & Amalfi. Decide if you want more costal or country vineyards, both are amazing.
Tuscany is a region not a town- and the region has numerous historical sites and fantastic countryside. I suggest you purchased a good guide book on Italy- Rick Steve’s book is excellent!
For a first time trip rome , Florence, Venice with day trips you will return
Venice :-)
Rome and Florence (including Siena and San Gimignano)
Two home bases is a great idea. I would personally choose Sorrento and Florence. Rome is beautiful but very busy.

Naples is the best option then you have access to Capri Ischia Amalfi...
You can do Rome as a day trip especially if you get the Fecciarossa early

Rome is a must! And it worth to stay at least 3 or 4 days.
Naples and Amalfi are very close, Amalfi can be a day trip from Naples, as well as Capri, Pompei, Sorrento, Ravello, Positano… All very typical and really beautiful sea views.
In Tuscany you have beautiful ancient cities or villages and beautiful country side.

Why "base" in these touristy places? Why not stay in smaller beach towns between Rome and Naples? Visit the cities for the day, then go back to smaller towns and relax... Sperlonga, Gaeta, Terracina, etc.

We just got back family of six. My last trips to Italy we jumped too much. So this time we were a week in Rome a week in Sicily and it was fantastic. It's so easy to try to cram too much in because there are so many lovely areas, but we really enjoyed this trip. I love Florence but didn't want the rushing feel and Sicily was the only part we hadn't been to. It is sooo beautiful.
Yup, Rome and Siena! Just booked the same for next May. We have extra time so are doing Ischia as well

We just came back from two weeks in Italy and we had 6 nights in Taormina a night either side at Catania, and then four nights in Rome. It was amazing, we have 15 yo and 18 yo and two parents so the art and history of Italy were fantastic, plus some time at the beach and of course, food 😍
Can anyone recommend where to stay In Tuscany? We would like a villa in the countryside, but central to explore to other areas.
You would love Sicily then
Split it between Rome and Florence. Do a day trip out Rome to Tivoli and one from Florence to Pisa/Lucca. Fly in one, out the other. Train between.
Rome and Positano home bases try to add more 3 precious days
Rome and tuscany, definitely
No ocean here lol

8 - 10 days goes by fast, if you are able to get more days, do it you won’t be sorry! Rome is VERY touristy, but…. So rich in history and May should not be that overwhelming with so many tourists! Good luck in your choices, watch utube to see areas of interest!
I would skip Naples. Rome and Sorrento. Stay in Sorrento. Take tours from there. Very easy. Take a boat trip to Capri.

I would start making sure it is 10 days not 8 . if u can make 2 weeks which I would recommend, at least 2 weeks, that would be perfect, and then you could combine Florence and Tuscany hills and Amalfi coast which we loved or Cinque Terre Italia, which is closer to Florence . I will write more knowing what your plan is. We loved Florence and Tuscany. I have an excellent guide for Tuscany with a big van. He is fun and fabulous. Amalfi beaches are rocky but the vibe and energy there is incredible, water clean and warm. you just need flip flops on the beach that is all.
Orvieto is amazing google it also we stayed in Maiori in the Amalfi coast much better than Amalfi or Positano but they may not suit your plans

Both are good choices. But if you want the water, I would suggest your home base in Sorrento, a good jumping off point to Amalfi Coast and Capri. You can also go to Pompeii from there. We did it in April 2023 and the weather was cool and not as crowded as later in the year. We loved Sorrento. We rented an apartment with VRBO within a 3 minute walk from Piazza Tasso, the main area. It was great. Lots of shops, restaurants, and grocery stores so you don't have to eat out every meal. We had a view of the Bay of Naples and Mt Vesuvius. I personally don't think Naples is near as good as Sorrento. Naples is a bit too rough and tumble for me. Watch out for pick pockets!

I’m in Italy. We were in Rome, Naples, took a boat to Ischia and now in Amalfi coast for a week. I know there are Naples lovers on here but I’m not one of them. Rome and Amalfi coast towns have been wonderful.

Rome then Napoli then Amalfi coast.
Tuscany next time 😁
Tuscany and a few days in Rome. In Tuscany you get much of the things you are looking for within reasonable distance and not much hussle.
How about Rome and Naples then?

You can do this! First get a good Guidebook, compare them at a book store. Rick Steves more laid back and less expensive more small locally owned places. Frommers and Fodor are higher budget places. I am there to see the sites not stay in a huge room. Watch videos, YouTube, join forums where ppl will ask questions. Then narrow down what you want to see. Every time you change locations it takes half a day. Pack, check out, get to train station find new place. There will be problems, it is part of the adventure. Don’t over plan. My family needs a rest day every 5-6 days where we just relax, go for a swim. We learn basic words and I make my daughter order food at one restaurant in the local language. Waiters become proud when she does!
Fort Tuscany I recommend Florence, it has many great museums, incredible history and romance and is in Tuscany. A great base.

We did Rome and Sorrento with day trips to Capri and rest of Amalfi Coast. If you choose this option make sure you do your day trips early in the morning to see nature and the sea as opposed to shopping mid day in the towns which is what many of the tours consist of. I felt the same way as you…as far as only 2 stops, taking it all in, nature. I would love to do Rome / Tuscany as well. Haven’t been to Tuscany yet.

Pick one city and one coast. Rome or Florence paired with Amalfi, Lake Como, Lake Garda, or Cinque Terra. Then day trip out of each place. Personally If I had to pick two for my first time I’d do Rome and Amalfi!

We are going for our second time (first with 3 teen kids) and doing Rome, Venice, Lake Como.

We just got back from a first trip. I would suggest Florence 100% and one other place depending on what you’d like to experience. We loved Florence for culture, history, and fun…all walkable!, We did a day trip to Chianti too. An e-bike tour sounded fun but we got rained out of ours. After Florence we did Sorrento and Positano for the coastal landscape vibe. I would suggest home base Sorrento and a day trips to Positano, Capri, Ischia, Almalfi etc. You won’t run out of ideas. You’ll be like, “we should have stayed longer”.
Perhaps Rome and Sorrento. Can access Napoli, Pompeii, Amalfi from there and you may need a break from a large city after Rome.

Rome and Tuscany are a must. Look into Airbnb’s…so affordable and relaxing…kitche
n and laundry are so handy too.
Rome and Siena.
ROME over Naples for sure

You're right to take it easy see less and get a better experience. You cannot go wrong with either of your options. If you have the opportunity then return and do the other.
My preferred choice is Tuscany. Even 10 days there you'll still have lots left to discover

Rome and Sorrento (by the coast south of Naples) makes a great second home base to Naples, Amalfi, Capri, Pompeii
Check VRBO for places and the owners are great resources
Went started in Rome, then went to Naples, Capri and Sorrento. Drove north and went to Venice, Florence, Pisa, Verona, Assisi and Milan. We were there 10 days.
Great idea to have two home bases. More people should do this rather then jumping from one place to another. Less tiring and you can go deeper!
Rome and Tuscany. Soooo much to see in both areas.

In October we're Going to Rome ,then naples then sorrento and pisitano
Rome should spend more days there if you've never been
Naples 2 to 3 days then Sorrento since it's closer to take the boat to Capri / anacapri
Then positano to do the amalfi coast and enjoy and get lost in positano streets lol

My only input would be, don’t go to the Amalfi coast for the beach if your from the east coast of the US. Their beaches are very rocky and unpleasant to walk on. We loved the Amalfi coast to tour the towns and would have been extremely disappointed if we went for the beach.
Ischia ❤️. We will arrive there on monday for the 7th time. We really loves that island 🇮🇹

If this is your first trip and going with your family, you should start in Rome and Florence. These cities and near areas have so much to see and enjoy- history, culture, incredible food, incredible day trips to beautiful towns.

If you want country side and beach go to the Adriatic side but if you’ve never been to Italy I’d hit all the usual touristy areas first but Italy is huge and 10 days flys by so pick a few places that are not too far from each other by train and start there, you’re going to have to come back to Italy another time to see the rest. I was there for 2 months last summer and I’ve gone almost every summer since I was a baby and I haven’t seen everything yet lol
Rome and Tuscany is so beautiful. Florence is a must see in my opinion!
Eu escolheria Roma e Toscana com certeza. Nunca Napoles

Sorrento is pristine.. You can take the circumvesuviano
into Naples when you want.. Naples is alive.. Enjoy your stay.. Plus there's a hertz in sorrento

Rome and Sorrento. All can be done with public transportation,
trains & ferries. Lots of great history in Rome, at least 3 nights. Sorrento is a great hub with the circumvesuviano
regional train from Naples allowing you to visit there, Herculenium , and Pompeii; then use ferry to visit Capri, and all of the towns along the Amalfi coast.
Please add Florence and Siena to your itinerary! You won't be sorry!
I can't imagine not including Rome if you've never been.

I was in Italy a few weeks ago for 11 days with my daughter and her two sons, 23 and 20. We flew into Rome from Newark Airport and got a transfer to Hotel Concordia in Rome..a nice hotel and location. We got 2 rooms ofcourse. We spent 3 days in Rome..had a morning Vatican tour...only planned thing we did..it was a hot day. We took a train from Rome to Naples and enjoyed the beautiful ride and countryside with so many farms. From Naples got a transfer..about
50 or 40 minutes to Maiori right on the coast and stayed at Hotel Panorama across from the ocean and lovely boardwalk. A wonderful town with excellent restaurants a very short walk..a block or so from hotel. We had designated beach chairs and umbrellas. Some small rocks on sandy beach..beautifu
l royal blue water.A wonderful family location..both hotels in both cities had rooftop buffet breakfasts included in price.Huge family suite at Hotel Panorama..with large balcony.
Rome and Florence. 5 and 5 days each. Naples is a day trip as is Ravello.
Our favorite is Napoli…the city has so much more to offer. We are there a week annually.

text:

text: Motion sickness… I get it really easy so I took a bottle of Dramamine with me and took one every morning because I knew I would be on trains and buses and golf carts and windy roads. It really saved me a few times. I got the nondrowsy 12 hour formula. ￼ I just wanted to share in case anyone had similar concerns. ￼

comments.comment_text: I have to say, I suffer from motion sickness myself but I've never experienced it on a train.

The drive from Positano to Naples I ended up on the side of the highway throwing up. And If you know the driving there it was very unsafe to do that. I took Dramamine, sat upfront and wore anti-nausea bracelets. I was a wreck.
But I had 2 8 hour boat days and a few train rides and didn’t need an medication. The driving there is intense.

I had a prescription for the patches from my doctor. That was my plan was to just put one of those on every three days. But it messed with me bad. I've never used them before. My vision was so blurry I couldn't read my phone. I felt dizzy and loopy for the first full day. I am glad I had Dramamine with me just in case. I tried finding some more at a pharmacy in Florence with no luck. But they may have had something else that would've helped. ￼

text: Suggestions for must visit places IN/AROUND Rome for 2 days trip...?

comments.comment_text:
If you only have two days I would focus on the more classic destinations. A tour of the historic center in Rome should be done, perhaps in the cooler hours of the day. Trastevere is also worthwhile, to visit there is Santa Cecilia which has wonderful Roman remains underneath and there are also lots of nice restaurants. Avoid the Vatican museums if you are short on time. It is hot at the Colosseum so it should be booked for early morning or late afternoon. Other museums worth a visit are the Capitoline museums or perhaps Doria Pamphili Palace. The Terme of Caracalla are also nice. Domus Aurea Is amazing but you have to book in advance.
Around Rome I recommend Tivoli with Villa Adriana or maybe Castel Gandolfo.

We didn’t have any issues getting chairs and umbrella on the Monterosso old town beach in July.

text: Hello everyone! Just had a quick question. How much time should we allow ourselves after landing to go through customs and baggage claim? I am just wondering, so I know an accurate time to purchase a train ticket after landing. my flight is scheduled to land at noon and I am planing on buying a train ticket to take us from Rome airport--> Napoli Centrale. Is it better to purchase train ticket in advance or can you buy the same day?

comments.comment_text: I'd definitely buy in advance. Give yourself at least an hour for customs. Sometimes it's quicker & sometimes longer.

Customs is unpredictable and often dependent on the time you land. I wouldn’t bother trying to book in advance. There is only one direct train a day from FCO to Napoli Central that leaves at 9:38. So unless your flight lands at least 2-3 hours before that you will likely have to go to Roma Termini first. The Frecce trains leave frequently from Termini (like half hour or less) and are usually not full. We took the train to Florence through Termini once, and although seems counterintuitiv
e, I’d take a taxi, Uber or car service to Termini. The Leonardo express station is at terminal 3, so if you arrive at one of the other terminals you have to get there first. Unless things have changed, we had a really long walk to get to our transfer…pullin
g our suitcase. A car will let you off in front and it is much easier to get to buy your ticket and get to your binario to Naples Centrale. Of course, you can easily purchase the tickets on line now, which wasn’t the case when we went. 🙃
We found because we had a child under age that it definitely took longer.
Buy tickets. Everything is a bit slower and takes longer…except driving. That’s at light speed.

Purchase in advance if possible and travel either business or first class. This is best for comfort and keeping your luggage close to you. Have a fantastic time.

I’m not sure about baggage and customs. I traveled with a carryon and it went quickly.
It took us about 2 hours to get our luggage in Rome so it’s hard to tell.😆
Where are you coming from? Direct flight?
First you go through immigration.. next collect baggage .. then customs is a walk through if nothing to declare... baggage can be 10 min or 60🤷‍♀️
Multiple flights are getting delayed and customs is sooo unpredictable. I wouldn’t buy your ticket in advanced. Unless it’s transferable, but even that might be a headache to get rescheduled.

the train from the airport to rome runs all the time and seats don't exactly run out
so it's actually smarter to book your train from rome to naples in advance for a few hours after landing. But for the train from the airport to rome, it's actually better to buy it right there at the ticket machine when you're done with customs andgot your luggage
I would buy it when you arrive, anything can go wrong , not worth the stress if your running late 🌻
So many flights are canceled or delayed that I’d wait.
I bought 3 hours from landing time. You have to take the train from the airport to Rome and then on to Naples.

You really can't say how long it will take you to go through customs etc...It all depends on how many flights have arrived and unfortunately there is no way you would be able to find out...also delays and flight ✈️ cancelled...I personally would wait until you have gone through these areas at the airport....🙃

Customs is last and takes no time at all if you have nothing to declare. However immigration then baggage claim is so hard to determine as very dependent on number of flights that arrive as yours does and staffing levels. Get your ticket after you exit....then no stress about timing etc.

text: Is riding a Vespa in Tuscany a thing and if so where is a good scenic ride. We will be staying in Orvieto and in Florence.

comments.comment_text:
There are various guided tours that will pull you around Tuscany, stopping at various locations. If you don't have previous scooter or motorcycle experience, this is what I'd recommend. Driving in Italy isn't for the feint of heart. Driving in a major city center is nuts and not for the inexperienced.

If you have riding experience, plan your own ride. Download an area map on Google Maps on your phone, slap the phone on a mount on the rental scooter.

When we went last month, we took a couple rentals out of New Tuscany Scooter Rental, which I recommend.
I pre-planned a route out of Florence, south through Strada, Greve, Montefioralle, Panzano, Castellina, and Radda, then back up through Volpaia. We didn't plan anything specific in each town, just stopping for sightseeing and food as we wanted. We made it as far as Panzano before turning back due to time concerns. The entire route would be doable if you're more focused on the ride than on the stops, but we have no regrets. It was definitely one of the best days of our trip.

Hopefully this Google Map link works for you.

Florence - Scooter Map

maps.app.goo.gl/

text:
Hello! My husband and I (ages 26) are planning to go on our first Europe trip next fall. Since we have never been we are anxious about how much money is necessary to have in the budget. We would like to do around a week in Italy. Aside from flights, how much would you save for this trip? We are open to staying in airbnbs or hotels. Also, how far in advance is best/recommended to book flights? Thanks 😊

Open to any first time European travel tips as well!

comments.comment_text:
I'd be budgeting, aside from flights, around €3000-€7000, depending which country you're from then convert that to your dollars. It depends if you prefer 3 star or 5 star accommodation. Can range from €150-€500 per night! Then factor in tours, trains/buses/
taxis & food too. Also some spending money.
I'd be booking flights 6mths in advance.
Book direct with hotels or through booking-com.

Best bet is check on Booking and airbnb in the cities/towns/
areas you want to viti for a ballpark of what you get for different prices. I'm a tight wad and spend most time out of the accommodation, so budget £+/-400 for a week. I just want safe, clean and convenient I budget £50 or so per day for main meal, coffee, transport, stuff. Then just pay whatever gallaries/
sites, etc cost. This is all over Europe, not just for Italy. Some people spend my week budget + in a day, so haha, all up to you. I never slum it. I shop around carefully.

Italy is not cheap these days in airb&b, or hotels . I go to Italy a lot and I stay in a 3 star hotel in Rome near the termini & that her night is €155per night and Florence airb&b is €181.00 per night for 2 people 🌻

text: What should I expect to pay per adult for food in Southern Italy? And a child per day? Just tying to get an around about idea as too how much we will Need for food. I have a 6,8 and 12 year old and myself and my husband. TIA

comments.comment_text: Breakfast around 10 euros, lunch 12-18 euros and dinner 18-26 euros depending on where you go.

Alternatively, if you eat simpler, a cappuccino and a brioche will cost about 4 euros. For me, a five euro sandwich from a bakery was usually enough for lunch. A splurge meal— a pizza and a couple glasses of the house white wine, could be had for under 15.
If you download the app The Fork, you can look at restaurant menus in the city you are visiting and it will give you an idea of prices. You can also use it to make reservations .

If we're talking 3 meals a day, I'd budget $15 for breakfast, $25 for lunch and $35 for dinner....or about $75pp per day. I'd do about 1/2 for kids meals. So for your family, I'd say about $200 per day. Obviously, some days will be much less but some days will be more so it will probably even out.
We shop the wonderful grocery stores and street markets preparing our own meals in our Airbnb. We do buy take away entrees too. Our food budget is not expensive.

This really depends where you’re eating. I’m about to order a Margherita pizza a town outside of Naples for €4.50. And my 5&7yo can split it.

Last week I spent €30 on two espressos and two croissants in capri.

Depends what you want to eat.Pizza,Spagh
etti or seefood? A Pizza or Spaghetti are 8-11,-€,seafood
can be 15-25€!
Always such questions from US citicen.What would you answer if I'm asking the same for NY and don't tell if I want to visit a McDonalds or a high level restaurant?

The food costs less than in the US. I think whatever you would spend when vacationing (we normally have a late breakfast and an early dinner and skip lunch), I would budget less than you would here. We were pleasantly surprised by the prices. Also does your hotel have free breakfast/
tours have lunch included? We don’t drink, so a big bottle of sparkling water, which we split, with dinner was only about 3 euros.
Always budget at you home town restaurant and cafe prices as a rough guide, it depends how and where you eat.
This really depends on your taste. You can eat very cheaply at a owner operated trattoria . Remember that cash gives you the better deal

I have my 3 daughters here now 10,11,13 yo we spend collectively 100 a day on food. I’m not sure where ppl are eating or how much but 2 adults and 3 kids should fine with 200 a day easy. We usually order 2 meals at dinner, grab a sandwich each for lunch and a pastry each for breakfast. This includes drinks and gelato lol this is for southern Italy strictly
Oh and get accommodations with breakfast!!
We were about 100-200 per day for 2 adults and 2 kids. We have smaller kids so they always split a meal at nicer places. We pretty much always got dessert at a drink as well.

I mean, pasta dishes at local trattorias and restaurants that are not near touristy hotspots are 10-16 euros, pizzas are around 6-10 euros. You normally buy sparkling or bottled water at 2-4 euros for a bigger bottle. There’s desserts, like gelatos that are on average 4 euros. Breakfast items are normally an espresso or a sweet pastry. Not a lot of American breakfasts to be found.
I gave myself and my daughter 2k euros for food for 17 days. I’m def. under budget. Food is cheaper than I thought.

For a family of 5 consider like 20/25 for the breakfast, maybe 75 for lunch and like 100 for dinner. Prices for all family members included, try to save money by eating in "trattorias" and "osterias" and avoid restaurants in the main squares
Ange Renae Nella Pringle

Dine in osterias or pizzerias. Ristorantes are more expensive. Avoid any place that has an English menu. Look for small family run places. I haven’t noticed children’s meals so for them you could probably share plates. Buy premade sandwiches for lunch. Supermarkets often have pre made meals or salads. Buy fruit. The quality of food products is high.

text:
EURAIL question 🚞

We are travelling through Italy & onto a few other countries using Eurail 10 day pass. We’ve paid to reserve seats on most trips on their website, which we’ve printed.

We have downloaded the app but we can’t see the exisiting tickets booked. The journeys are blank, it hasn’t synced. Do we manually add our trips to the app and rely on the paper copies for the paid seats?

What do we need to do at the train station? Also, how do we “activate” our Eurail pass tickets as I’ve seen a lot of talk about fines? 😅🤷🏽‍♀️

Grazie 🙏🏼

comments.comment_text:
There is a Eurail Interrail FB group you can join.
You need to update the Rail Planner with your pass details including your passport number.
You neeed to use the "planner" (bottom left) to find the trip with the to and from station details. Once you have the correct time you save the journey to your pass. On the day of travel go to "My Pass" and you should be able to find the journey and you have to move the toggle (top right) from left to right to activate the journey (it turns yellow).
If you are on a journey that does turn up in the planner you have to enter the details manually (in the "from" station type a random word like dream it will say it cannot find that station and give you the option to add it manually.
There is a lot of helpful information on the FB group page and also the Eurail site online and Man in seat 61 (lots of rail info)

text:
We are travelling to Rome in January with our children,
Any advice and tips would be greatly appreciated 😊

I see recommendations for Italy always mention the same cities over and over, especially in Tuscany. As someone who lives in the region, if you have the chance to visit and move around by car, I suggest checking out other places like:

Populonia/ Golfo di Baratti

Pitigliano (town built in tuff, on the border with Lazio region)

Capalbio (check Giardino dei Tarocchi by artist Niki de Saint Phalle; the town of Capalbio is incredible)

Bolgheri/Castagneto Carducci (if you are into wines)

Bibbona (village overlooking the Tyrrhenian sea in the province of Livorno, very beautiful nature and beach)

Gombitelli (a little gem on the hills of Camaiore, Lucca province; famous for the art of cured meats)

Seravezza (where the Medici’s would retreat during summer; beautiful palazzo Mediceo; in the marble quarry area of Versilia)

Saturnia, Venturina (for hot springs)

Livorno (check Terrazza Mascagni, Quartiere Venezia; birth place of Modigliani)

Check Certosa di Calci (near Pisa)

Viareggio (one of the oldest summer destinations by the beach in Tuscany; Puccini used to holiday here, Villa Puccini is here, Belvedere Puccini in Torre del Lago, neighboring town between Viareggio and Pisa where Puccini had his hunting lodge; check out old Liberty style bathhouses on Viareggio’s promenade; poets like Shelley stayed here for a while, artist Escher got married in Viareggio)

Garfagnana area if you are into nature, check Parco dell’Orecchiella; Isola Santa, Vagli if you fancy zip line. Parco delle Apuane if you want to stay in the alps where marble for Michelangelo’s sculptures were sourced from; lodges in Campo Catino, breathtaking views and great silence.

Abbazia di San Galgano (in Siena)

Lajatico (near Pisa, Teatro del Silenzio)

Peccioli (province of Pisa, art throughout the town)

These are just a few of the gems you may be missing if you stick to the usual spots.

text: What’s a good amount of spending money to have in Italy for 3 weeks for 1 person doing it solo? I will be going next May by myself. It won’t be for accomodation or tours of the main things as that will all be paid for previously. Thank you

comments.comment_text: We use our US credit cards spending very little cash euros.

Depends as everyone is so different.
Food wise, anywhere from min €60 a day or more (depending on how many gelatos you want 😉, alcoholic beverages, or whether you prefer fine dining or a panini or pizza, or if your breakfast is included with your accommodation).

Allow extra for buses/trains/
taxis, maybe average it to €20 a day.
Access public bathrooms €1-€2 per day!
Spending money/shopping - it differs for everyone. If just souvenirs, then €100-€300 for total trip. Depends if Olive Oils Limoncello, jewellery, pottery, linen etc.
So €2000-€3500 for whole trip. Only take €500 cash with you. The rest on your Cc or travelcard.
I usually try to budget $100 a day. If I spend less, then I have extra the next day. If I don't spend it all by the end, then I get to come home with extra money!!!!

Again depends, for us we cook breakfast and eat very light dinner - so never restaurant , will eat out lunch and do not drink coffee and coming for winter , prob will not do much gelato, therefore maybe 20-30 euro a day per person maybe more if we go to market to buy something , I can not imagine 100 a day ￼, so it all depends on ur spending habit
Take what you can afford and spend what you wish for😎🥂🤔🤔🤔

I travel every year to Italy , have done all the sightseeing in lots of towns & I work on €100 per day , I take cash €1000 as I only ever take money out of post offices as you go in, & Italian banks you can’t enter unless you have a swipe card , & not often I use atms🌻

text:
Hello Everyone,

I would like to ask You for an advice on how to travel around European countries in terms of everything necessary and planning.

I’m currently 20, between my second and third year in college and since I was 14 years old, I’ve wanted to make some travelling to few specific places in the world - I’ve decided to do it around Europe first, then maybe North America later, and lastly, the Far East Asian countries. As of yet I haven’t done any of those travellings, I’m planning to do in the next following year or two or more. I’ve only been to two small trips to my neighbouring countries, one of which is across the Baltic Sea. The best conclusion I’ve gathered from them is that I don’t like trips that are widely popularised by Western tourists - that is, fly somewhere by plane, sleep in a hotel, see some landmarks in a stereotypically touristic fashion. I’ve noticed that this doesn’t bring me enough satisfaction and decided that if I want to do some travelling I would like to try make it a one big long trip, where I would explore most of the continent on a single trip, using the cheapest possible means. For example, sleeping using couchsurfing services, or maybe at hostel, travelling to places using hitchhiking or trains (also try to not use airplanes at all), seeing some landmarks and, most importantly, getting to know local people and their mentality, views on their country as well as how they tent to live everyday. All this in the cheapest possible way since my expectations of comfort at minimum at best. I’m myself perfectly healthy as well as rather athletic, that’s why rather running around the cities I want to explore rather than walking is more suitable for me - almost exploring like some sandbox video game character.

My questions about all these are as following:
1. I’m currently planning to go on my planned trip around Europe during the warm months, mainly from the end of April to the beginning of October. Do you think that much time is a good idea, or is it unnecessary long and maybe a three month time during college student summer vacation, from the beginning of June to the end of September.
2. What should I provide for myself to be comfortable exploring such terrains on foot? As of now I know I should get:

- An EKUZ to be eligible for a healthcare in the countries of the European Union.
- A passport if I’m travelling to a country which is outside the European Union, as long as I’m staying in the EU, my home country ID card is enough. Correct me if I’m wrong.
- From what I’ve read, the mobile internet data is available without the need of buying a separate SIM cart, as long as I’m still in the countries of the EU. Correct me if I’m wrong about this information.
- A budget of € EUR money. I’m planning on having it mainly through credit card as well as having little in cash. Do You have any recommendations on a credit card provider companies, which would be the best for a trip I’m planning?
- A couch surfing app. As of yet, I haven’t used any of such apps, that’s why I would like to ask You, which app would You recommend as the best.
- An Interrail/Eurail train ticket pass of a certain amount of days available to use throughout a month or months. Is there any more providers of such tickets or these two are the only ones? Which one for me, an European citizen would be the best?

I’m sorry for such a lengthy post, however I wanted to ensure You that I do not have the faintest idea about providing for such lengthy trip. I would like to ask You for every single, even the tiniest bit of seemingly obvious information that would come in handy in terms of planning such a trip and ensuring my safety and comfort.

Hope Everyone understood my post. Thank you for helping me and providing some advices!

comments.comment_text: Great questions and great attitude. My first trip was to India and I can't believe how unprepared I was and TBH terrified in a cab from the airport seeing all the street sleepers, then later looking down from my guesthouse window at the Rats as big as cats fought amongst the refuse. But you learn and adapt and grow. So my only advice is have an adventure more than a holiday and deal with whatever challenges come your way rather than try to imagine and overprepare. Most of it's a waste of time.

text: I looked at the weather if Florence. We are going next year about this time ans know it will be hot. We are from Texas so kinda used to hear. But the weather map says possible disruption due to extreme heat. Anyone know what that means ?

comments.comment_text: Over 110 degrees. Italy has little or no AC. Americans are accustomed to bone chilling AC inside accommodations and vehicles. Plus, Europe has so much hot pavement.

Actually in south Europe and part of middle Europe discovers a big heat period, means it has more the 40 degrees Celsius. Means more than 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Just be aware that some of the sightseeing things may be closed during the day longer than usual.
Yes, they are not equipped like Texas is. In time now and it got so much hotter today. It’s not stop sweat fest. Everyone. But the rooms with mini splits are worth it.

They shut down outdoor attractions in the afternoon when it’s this hot. I was in Florence and Pisa yesterday - and we didn’t experience any outages - but we drank TONS of water, rested, and found shade often. I know it’s not Italy - but I just read that the Acropolis closed from noon-5pm yesterday due to the heat.
Europe is very hot this year!!!!!

Europe is experiencing an unprecedented heat wave this summer-so while it gets hot during the summer, this type of heat is unusual. When we were there in June a few years ago, it averaged the mid 20s. (Celsius), it was perfectly lovely. So perhaps next year temps will return closer to normal.
It means that some tourist attraction may be closed during the hottest part of the day. Many of them have little or no ac. It becomes dangerous to the tourists.

The thing is that Florence together with Bologna is one of the hottest Italian cities. It is sorrounded by hills so all the humidity stays above the city. So the temperature is not the real point,but it's all about humidity. And believe me ,we 've a lot 🤣

In August 2016 I was in Europe. England was very warm but not terribly hot. Paris, on the other hand, was too hot for sleeping. No A/C in the hotel, but a fan ran continuously. I couldn’t sleep it was so hot.
In extreme heat people will be dropping in the streets, power might fail, services could be overwhelmed.

When people kept telling me it was hot, I didn’t understand because I’m from Texas and it’s HOT here. However, here you can step inside and cool off. In Italy, inside everywhere almost, except our hotel room that we cranked down cold, was hot. There is nowhere to cool off so I felt like i never stopped being hot the whole trip.
Well you dont know for sure what weather will be after a year ;)

text: We are planning a trip next October. We would like to visit Rome,Florence and Venice. Do you suggest using a travel agent or booking it on our own?

comments.comment_text: I think you can book on your own if you like. Travel between those places is easy. That said, if you already have an agent, it cannot hurt to see what they come up it price-wise.
On your own!! they are the most three visited places in Italy absolutely easy to get tips and ideas from. If you give yourself enough time, you absolutely can do it on your own to plan.
Most travel agency tours include breakfast and some dinners. Lunch is on your own with free time.

We used a travel agent to help plan our individualized trip(not a big tour group) While we knew what cities we wanted to visit, and the basic things we wanted to do in each city, we found it invaluable to have someone knowledgeable of the area to plan/book the details. Booking our hotel, private transfers and trains as well as the tours we chose was incredibly helpful and timesaving. But I know other people enjoy doing the whole thing on their own-so it depends on your preferences.
